paragraphs.text:
%md

# Reading with Neo4j Connector for Apache Spark

Docs [here](https://neo4j.com/developer/spark/reading/).

For this example we will use the Neo4j Movie Database.

msg.data:
Reading with Neo4j Connector for Apache Spark

Docs here.

For this example we will use the Neo4j Movie Database.

paragraphs.text:
%neo4j

CREATE (TheMatrix:Movie {title:'The Matrix', released:1999, tagline:'Welcome to the Real World'})
CREATE (Keanu:Person {name:'Keanu Reeves', born:1964})
CREATE (Carrie:Person {name:'Carrie-Anne Moss', born:1967})
CREATE (Laurence:Person {name:'Laurence Fishburne', born:1961})
CREATE (Hugo:Person {name:'Hugo Weaving', born:1960})
CREATE (LillyW:Person {name:'Lilly Wachowski', born:1967})
CREATE (LanaW:Person {name:'Lana Wachowski', born:1965})
CREATE (JoelS:Person {name:'Joel Silver', born:1952})
CREATE
(Keanu)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Neo']}]->(TheMatrix),
(Carrie)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Trinity']}]->(TheMatrix),
(Laurence)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Morpheus']}]->(TheMatrix),
(Hugo)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Agent Smith']}]->(TheMatrix),
(LillyW)-[:DIRECTED]->(TheMatrix),
(LanaW)-[:DIRECTED]->(TheMatrix),
(JoelS)-[:PRODUCED]->(TheMatrix)

CREATE (Emil:Person {name:"Emil Eifrem", born:1978})
CREATE (Emil)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:["Emil"]}]->(TheMatrix)

CREATE (TheMatrixReloaded:Movie {title:'The Matrix Reloaded', released:2003, tagline:'Free your mind'})
CREATE
(Keanu)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Neo']}]->(TheMatrixReloaded),
(Carrie)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Trinity']}]->(TheMatrixReloaded),
(Laurence)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Morpheus']}]->(TheMatrixReloaded),
(Hugo)-[:ACTED_IN {roles:['Agent Smith']}]->(TheMatrixReloaded),
(LillyW)-[:DIRECTED]->(TheMatrixReloaded),
(LanaW)-[:DIRECTED]->(TheMatrixReloaded),
(JoelS)-[:PRODUCED]->(TheMatrixReloaded)

%md

## Reading relationship

In the following example we are going to read all the `Movie` and `Person` nodes that are connected by the `DIRECTED` relationship.

We then filter just the rows that which `Person`'s name ends with `Wachowski`.

msg.data:
Reading relationship

In the following example we are going to read all the Movie and Person nodes that are connected by the DIRECTED relationship.

We then filter just the rows that which Person’s name ends with Wachowski.

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Reading relationship as a map

We read the same query, but this time we can use the `source` and `target` fields as a Map by setting the `relationship.nmodes.map` option to `true`.

More on `relationship.nmodes.map` option [here](http://5.9.211.195:8000/neo4j-spark-docs/1.0.0/reading.html#_node_mapping).

msg.data:
Reading relationship as a map

We read the same query, but this time we can use the source and target fields as a Map by setting the relationship.nmodes.map option to true.

More on relationship.nmodes.map option here.

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Reading by Cypher query

You can write a direct cypher read query using the `query` option.

msg.data:
Reading by Cypher query

You can write a direct cypher read query using the query option.

paragraphs.text:
val df = spark.read
    .format("org.neo4j.spark.DataSource")
    .option("url", "bolt://neo4j:7687")
    .option("authentication.type", "basic")
    .option("authentication.basic.username", "neo4j")
    .option("authentication.basic.password", "password")
    .option("query", "MATCH (n:Movie {title: 'Unforgiven'})-[r]-(p:Person) RETURN labels(p) as labels, type(r) as rel, p.name as name")
    .load
    
df.show()

msg.data:
+--------+--------+----------------+
|  labels|     rel|            name|
+--------+--------+----------------+

paragraphs.text:
val stream = spark.readStream.format("org.neo4j.spark.DataSource")
    .option("url", "bolt://neo4j:7687")
    .option("authentication.type", "basic")
    .option("authentication.basic.username", "neo4j")
    .option("authentication.basic.password", "password")
    .option("labels", "Movie")
    .load()
    
val query = stream.where("title LIKE 'movie %'").writeStream.format("console").start()
query.awaitTermination(60*1000)

msg.data:
<console>:24: error: not found: value query
       query.stop()
       ^
